Aside from the work done at Screen Rant, Timothy writes film reviews for small news outlets and runs his own movie-themed YouTube channel.

title: 10 Massive Story Spoilers For Baldur's Gate 3
text:
Although Baldur's Gate 3 is a game built on player choice, the main plot still manages to be packed with twists and reveals to keep players guessing.
In a game as massive as Baldur’s Gate 3, it should come as no surprise that there are twists and turns to the plot. With such an epic plot full of adventure and romance, these twists can catch some off guard. From character motivations to shocking identity reveals, BG3's story has plenty to keep even those coming back for yet another playthrough on their toes.
[Warning: The following article contains spoilers for Baldur's Gate 3.]
Set over 120 years after Baldur's Gate 2: Shadows of Amn, Baldur's Gate 3 sees the rise of a new dangerous cult linked to mind flayers and seeking world domination. With many different endings that depend on choices made throughout the plot, BG3 cannot be fully experienced in a single playthrough. With that in mind, although there is still plenty to surprise during a repeat playthrough, there are some key story moments that will only be as impactful once.
Related: "An Iconic, Engaging Mess Of Brilliant Ideas": Baldur's Gate 3 Review
Once in the Shadow-Cursed Lands in Act 2 Mizora, Wyll’s patron, will pay the camp a little visit. She has a mission for Wyll, and the rest of the party to rescue one of Zariel’s ‘assets’ who has been grabbed by the cultist of the Absolute. This is a great opportunity to negotiate with Mizora to try to free Wyll from his contract with her.
Related: All Baldur's Gate 3 Characters That Can Join Camp, Ranked
The twist comes when reaching the Mind Flayer Colony under Moonrise Towers and discovering that Mizora herself is the one who needs rescuing and is trapped in one of the mind flayer pods. There is then a choice to save her or leave her to die, but as killing her will also mean Wyll dies as well, letting her out of the pod is the best option.
Once in Act Three of Baldur’s Gate 3, the party will hear about a new crime boss in the city known as the Stone Lord. This new criminal is terrorizing the other criminal guilds who ask for the party’s aid in dealing with this issue. In particular, Nine-Fingers, the leader of the Guild, will want to talk to Jaheira, where she will reveal that the Stone Lord is none other than Jaheira’s old companion, Minsc. Hearing this information is one thing, but when it is confirmed by confronting the Stone Lord at the Counting House, nothing feels quite like seeing Minsc in the role of a villain.
Related: Baldur's Gate 3: Why Minsc's Return Is Such A Big Deal
Minthara is a drow paladin found in the Shattered Sanctum in Act One, who will ask the party to reveal the location of the Druid Grove. Siding with her will mean the end for all the druids and tielfings there and is one of the more morally objectionable decisions in Baldur’s Gate 3. However, what isn’t immediately obvious is that Minthara is simply a thrall under the control of the Absolute.
Related: Baldur's Gate 3: Pros & Cons Of Romancing Minthara In BG3
After siding with her in Act One, she can be met again in Moonrise Towers, where the other members of the cult have turned on her and sentenced her to death. Once she is rescued, it is revealed that just like many of the other True Souls the party has met, Minthara's mind was not entirely her own.
At the beginning of Act Three, the sleeping party is ambushed by githyanki and the Dream Guardian, who has been protecting everyone from the Absolute, calls out for help. Entering the Astral Prism leads to one of the biggest twists in the game as it is revealed that the Guardian is who they appear.
Pleading for the party’s help is a mind flayer calling themself the Emperor, explaining that they didn’t think the player character would help if they knew the Dream Guardian’s true identity. Refusing to help will mean a game over, but it is shocking to meet the party’s savior face-to-face for the first time and see who they really are.
Just as the party is coming to grips with working with a mind flayer, BG3 throws another twist with the Emperor at the team. Delving into the Wyrmway beneath Baldur’s Gate, the party can discover even more about their illithid ally. After battling an undead dragon, it is revealed that the Emperor was once Balduran, famed adventurer and founder of Baldur’s Gate. When asked about it, the Emperor will show their life through flashbacks, including how they became a mind flayer.
Related: Should You Help The Emperor In Baldur's Gate 3?
In the beginning, it is insinuated by the Dream Guardian that they are the one keeping the party safe from the Absolute with their own powers. However, at the same time, it is revealed that they are a mind flayer called the Emperor. It is also revealed that the true source of the party’s protection is the imprisoned githyanki, Prince Orpheus. Orpheus is the son of Mother Gith, who freed her people from the mind flayers with her power to block their influence, a power she passed onto her son. Later in BG3, the party will face the decision of whether or not to free Orpheus, but his initial reveal is one that stands out.
Related: Baldur's Gate 3: Should You Free Orpheus In BG3 Or Side With The Emperor?
Very early in Baldur’s Gate 3, the party will learn about a magical artifact called the Nightsong that is supposed to be hidden under the temple of Selune. A wizard named Lorroakan has even hired a band of adventurers to find it, but they found themselves outmatched by the goblins. However, it is not until the end of Act Two that the Nightsong is revealed to be a person, not an item, the aasimar daughter of Selune, Dame Aylin. Learning that the Nightsong is a person puts a whole new slant on Lorroakan’s search, especially once it is revealed that he knows what the Nightsong really is.
Shadowheart is one of the more complex companions in Baldur’s Gate 3, with a mysterious past that she can only partially remember. However, if she is encouraged to turn away from Shar, her personal questline will eventually lead to a massive and heartbreaking reveal. Shadowheart learns that her parents were followers of Selune, Shar’s sister and rival and that she was taken as part of that rivalry.
Related: Jennifer English On How Baldur's Gate 3's Shadowheart Was "Her Dream Job"
But it gets even more tragic as Shadowheart’s parents are revealed to be alive, held prisoner by Shar, and used to torment Shadowheart. At the end of the quest, Shadowheart is forced to make the choice: return to Shar and free her parents, or stay free herself and let them die.
Raphael is a character met very early on in BG3, and once he has properly introduced himself, the party will learn he is a cambion, wishing to make a deal with them. However, the terms of the deal are unclear, and it is not until Act Three that Raphael’s full plan is explained. Raphael is, in fact, the son of Mephistopheles, one of the rulers in the Nine Hells, and he wants to make a deal to put him ahead of his father.
Raphael will offer the Orphic Hammer to free Prince Orpheus and work with him in place of the Emperor. In exchange, Raphael wants the Crown of Karsus, which is currently being used to control the elderbrain. The Crown will allow him to take control of the Hells and eventually beyond, and should the party take the deal, Raphael will further explain his grant plan in a post-credits cutscene.
At the beginning of BG3, the enemy seems to be a strange new cult, worshiping a new god and controlling its followers with mind flayer tadpoles. However, it is not until Act Two that the true threat is revealed, as the cult is a front for the Dead Three, Bhaal, Bane, and Myrkul, who once again are attempting world domination.
This is a fantastic and clever way to link Baldur’s Gate 3 to its predecessors and without using the same paths that had been trodden before. However, there is a further twist at the very end when the elder brain explains that it was the true genius behind the entire plan and used the Dead Three Chosen to bring them the Crown of Karsus and build an army for them to set in motion the Grand Design.

title: Batman and Man-Bat Fight to the Death in Horror-Style Cosplay the DCEU Shouldn't Ignore
text:
Batman has been fighting brutal battles against Man-Bat for years now, with a new cosplay image pitting them against one another in live-action!
Batman has been locked in a never-ending battle against the vile villains of his rogues gallery for decades now, with the monstrous Man-Bat being one of his most dangerous and constant threats. And now, in a cosplay image featuring the two, Batman has his work cut out for him in a bloody brawl against Man-Bat that would fit right at home in the live-action movie space!
Posted on social media via Instagram, @all_starcosplay is the go-to cosplay account for all things Batman and Robin related, with the images shared by them bringing to life some of The Dark Knight and Boy Wonder’s best and most iconic comic book looks.
Dressing in various homemade batsuits like Batman’s all-yellow anti-Green Lantern outfit, his New 52 redesign, and more recently, a Batman x Doctor Fate look, @all_starcosplay has also dabbled in creating costumes for Damian Wayne’s Robin with both his new and original set of duds making an appearance on @all_starcosplay’s page, to name a few.
Related: Epic DC Cosplay Unleashes Batman's "Doctor Fate" Form
Working to develop a serum that would allow humans to mimic a bat’s sonar senses before testing it on himself to unexpected and horrifying results, Dr. Kirk Langstrom’s transformation into Man-Bat brought him directly into conflict with the Caped Crusader of Gotham City, kicking off a rivalry that has lasted for over half a century. Unfortunately for Batman, that rivalry has turned bloody on more than one occasion, with the good man Langstrom used to be nearly impossible to bring back when in this vicious state — something @all_starcosplay expertly highlights with this latest cosplay edit.
Helped along by the photoshop skills of @pixelens._, it’s made immediately apparent that @all_starcosplay knows what they’re doing when it comes to not only dressing as a comic-accurate version of Batman but when choosing the villain he faces off with as well. Pinned flat on his back as Man-Bat ruthlessly bares down on him in a fit of rage, @all_starcosplay’s Batman fights for his life as he attempts to beat back the monster who has forced a disadvantage that Bats can't afford. Editing in a surprisingly realistic Man-Bat on top of some choice blood spatter effects to hammer home Batman's horrific dilemma, @all_starcosplay and @pixelens._ are shown here to have elevated their cosplay game even further than usual by turning what could have been a simple shot into something far more brutal and terrifying.
Mentioning how a live-action film featuring Man-Bat as the main antagonist would be their “dream Batman movie,” @all_starcosplay makes a case for a horror-tinged tale pitting these two characters against one another, an idea made even more sound thanks to this image acting as a successful proof of concept. As of now, Batman and Man-Bat have yet to cross paths in Hollywood, but with the talents of @all_starcosplay and @pixelens._ creating inspiring cosplay photos like this one, that reality feels closer than ever.
Source: @all_starcosplay

title: Even Dragon Ball Fans Missed The Real Reason Vegeta Became A Villain in Super
text:
Vegeta became a villain again in Dragon Ball Super, but this actually has a great explanation and it's connected to Destruction and Ultra Ego.
Although fans were undoubtedly excited when Vegeta briefly reverted to his villainous ways during Dragon Ball Super's Granolah the Survivor Arc, this seemed quite sudden and unexpected. However, the series already explained why it happened, and subsequently proved that the Saiyan Prince would likely never suffer another relapse like that again.
Vegeta turns on Goku in chapter #76 of Dragon Ball Super, going off to fight Granloah on his own, but what Vegeta mutters to himself when the Cerealean is about to kill him demonstrates that Beerus led him to believe that he needed to change as a person to effectively wield the Power of Destruction (Hakai). In chapter #69 of Dragon Ball Super, Beerus tells Vegeta that his own power as a God of Destruction is unbounded because he only thinks about destruction, and that if Vegeta wanted to wield Destruction, he would have to destroy any stray thoughts he had.
At the time, Beerus was chiding Vegeta for spending too much time feeling responsible for the sins of the Saiyan race. However, Vegeta clearly interpreted Beerus' words as a need to return to his old, ruthless ways. During the fight against Granloah, Vegeta forces his opponent to destroy the ruins of his list civilization, and then even attacks Goku, telling him he would rather die than team up with him again. This seemed a completely random turn to fans, but it all makes sense because Vegeta was actually trying to master his new power, which came to fruition with his Ultra Ego transformation.
However, as proved by his later apology to Beerus, Vegeta was only fighting dirty against Granolah and said those horrible things to Goku because he was trying to wield Destruction in the most effective way, as Beerus told him to. This would explain why Vegeta is able to drop acting like he once did almost too quickly, as though nothing even happened. Surely enough, soon after that Vegeta teams up with Goku again, and the two Saiyans witness together the memories of Bardock, creating an even stronger bond over the legacy of their species.
So even though many fans may have felt that Dragon Ball Super promised to make Vegeta a villain again and then failed to deliver, Beerus' comments to Vegeta about how he could master Destruction and then Vegeta's admission about how he failed to revert to how he once was all explain everything perfectly. Vegeta's return to villainy failed because he was trying to be someone he no longer was, and Dragon Ball Super was just giving fans one last glimpse of this version of the Saiyan Prince before shutting the door on that chapter of his life for good.

title: Who Is Ravonna Renslayer? Loki's Marvel Villain & Kang Link Explained
text:
Judge Renslayer is a primary character in Loki season 1 and 2. Here's who Ravonna Renslayer is in the comics, and what her connection is to Kang.
In Loki, Judge Ravonna Renslayer, an agent with the Time Variance Authority (TVA), an organization responsible for maintaining the proper flow of time in the MCU, is played by Gugu Mbatha-Raw. Ravonna Renslayer has a wealth of comic book history to back her up as a character. Crucially, her comic history links her strongly to Kang the Conquerer, the time-traveling, multiverse-hopping villain who is set to be a large part of the MCU's upcoming future.
Throughout Loki Mbatha-Raw's role as Ravonna Renslayer is both memorable and divisive. While she plays a friend to Mobius, the Loki season 1 ending - and the first episode of season 2 - paint her in a more complicated light. Flashbacks demonstrate her callousness in following TVA rule as she worked as an agent to collect even child variants like Sylvie. In the comics, Ravonna is known best as the long-time love interest of Kang the Conqueror, the villain intent on ruling all timelines. Here’s everything to know about Loki’s antagonistic TVA judge, her comics origin, and link to Kang.
Related: Everything We Know About Loki Season 3
Mbatha-Raw’s Loki casting was announced in February 2020. At the time, reports did not state which character she’d be playing in the Disney+ series. However, it was revealed her role would be that of the leading lady. Judge Renslayer's role in season 1 provided more context for this, showing Ravonna's time in the TVA, and her turn from being intensely committed to the faction - hunting down Sylvie and turning on Mobius for the TVA - to becoming one of its biggest critics in season 2 in order to try and bring about meaningful change for the institution, and protect the recently reformed multiverse.
This serves to flesh out a figure who both serves an antagonistic role, but who also has some real moral complexity, making her future in the Loki season 2 cast all the more exciting. Given Renslayer's comic origins, it seems she may well play just as integral a role in the second season as she did in the first.
Ravonna Renslayer was first introduced in 1965’s Avengers #23 and has gone by several different aliases, including Terminatrix and Temptress. She was born in the late 40th century and is the daughter of King Carelius, a ruler of one of Kang’s kingdoms. While Ravonna doesn’t have any superhuman abilities, she is highly intelligent and is skilled in hand-to-hand combat and proficient in the use of advanced future technology. Using a teleporter and other futuristic tech to detect energy fields, Ravonna is capable of traveling through time.
She has gone up against the Fantastic Four and the Avengers, who attempted to stop her from retrieving the Ultimate Nullifier, a weapon capable of destroying anyone the wielder wishes. In this instance, Renslayer wanted to destroy Kang the Conqueror, who opted to kill the Avengers rather than save her while visiting with the Grandmaster. At other times, she’s been the Avengers’ ally (though it’s short-lived), working with them to defeat Kang from taking over the 40th century. Renslayer is relentless, passionate, and incredibly capable. No matter what Renslayer got up to, however, she proved how clever and formidable a foe and ally (depending on the day) she could be sans powers.
Ravonna Renslayer first crossed paths with the time-traveling Kang when he attempted to conquer her kingdom and fold it into his growing empire in the 40th century. For a long time, Kang’s love for Renslayer was one-sided, and she despised him because of his imperialistic ways. When the Avengers showed up to defeat Kang, she initially joined them to do so in a bid to stop him. Due to his love for Renslayer, Kang allowed the kingdom to rebel against his plans because he hoped Ravonna would change her mind and marry him. Kang was certainly smitten considering Ravonna is the only ruler he didn’t kill while seizing control.
When Kang’s general attempts to assassinate him, Ravonna sacrifices herself to save him, putting her in a coma until Kang could find a way to revive her. Ravonna becomes Kang’s greatest love and greatest nemesis - someone who loved him, then sought revenge and killed him. While the time-displaced princess eventually returns Kang’s feelings, she often feels betrayed by his actions. He’d much rather conquer the timeline or try and kill the Avengers than save her, and Ravonna grew tired of coming in second place to his diabolical schemes. Either way, her love-hate relationship with Kang plays a big role in her story. At one point, Ravonna even becomes the ruler of Chronopolis, a realm Kang created outside of time.
Related: 10 Burning Questions Loki Season 2 Can Finally Answer
Judge Renslayer’s link to Kang is crucial. Her presence in Loki foreshadowed the show's plans to bring the time-traveling villain into the MCU as early on as the series. It’s important to note Jonathan Majors was officially cast as Kang the Conqueror in Ant-Man 3, which means plans for his role in the MCU were already in motion. Considering Ant-Man came up with the idea to use the Quantum Realm to time travel, it makes sense that Kang would be a villain in the film. However, bringing Major's Kang into the MCU at the end of Loki season 1 allows for more build-up before he appears in later movies, and helps to develop the complex character more thoroughly.
It's unclear how much of Ravonna's origin story has been retained by the MCU, and how much of it might come into play later, if at all. Ravonna's variant is shown to the TVA as a school teacher who very much is not a princess in the 40th century. Additionally, while she knows a lot of the TVA's secrets, it is unclear how she knows them, how much she knows about Kang's existence, and whether Miss Minutes plays some role in the relationship between the two. However, Loki season 2 is sure to explore more about the Renslayer, and could well angle into adapting more of her comic storyline for the MCU.
The MCU has played fast and loose with comic backstories before, so it's no surprise that it's seemingly the same for Ravonna Renslayer. Loki season 2 has a lot of opportunities to further expand the character, potentially allowing for some aspects from the comic to be enmeshed alongside an entirely new and exciting story, whenever and wherever that takes her.

title: Gen V Episode 5 Trailer Clarifies Episode 4’s Ending (& It Goes Beyond Marie)
text:
The trailer for Gen V episode 5 clarifies the mystery surrounding episode 4's ending, revealing that what happened goes far beyond Marie.
Warning: SPOILERS ahead for Gen V episode 4!
A new trailer for Gen V episode 5 reveals the mystery surrounding episode 4's ending goes beyond Marie - and has major implications for the rest of the series. At the end of episode 4, the main students arrived at Dr. Cardosa's house to subdue Sam, who went there to kill the doctor for his involvement in the Woods. While Marie is trying to get Sam to calm down, she suddenly wakes up in bed next to Jordan.
Now, Prime Video has released a new trailer for Gen V episode 5, revealing Marie's sudden time jump didn't just impact her. In the trailer, Jordan reveals they are missing multiple days of time, which is implied to have impacted everyone who was at Cardosa's house. The trailer also promises a look inside Sam's psyche as he battles people he thinks are puppets.
Prior to Marie waking up in bed with Jordan, she had been trying to calm Sam down after Emma grew in size and pinned him to the ground. However, now that her and her friends have lost time following their attempt to save Cardosa, it's unclear what the final results of their efforts were. It's also unknown why they lost time, or how it's connected to Gen V's ongoing Woods mystery.
Since everyone involved in the incident has been impacted, it's likely a Supe is behind their memory loss. Sam may have more powers than he's letting on, wiping the students' memories so he can escape without them every finding out where he went. Another possibility is that Cardosa called a Supe who knows about the Woods to step in, erasing Marie and her friends' memories to ensure whatever happened in those missing days is never discovered.
Now that Gen V has introduced a new memory loss mystery, it appears the group discovering the truth behind the Woods will be much harder than they thought. Perhaps the mystery surrounding the Woods will be used to set up a dangerous new storyline in The Boys season 4, which is expected to follow-up one some plot points from the spinoff. Now that the Woods' conspiracy has deepened, it will prove even harder to discover everything going on below Godolkin.
Source: Prime Video

title: When Loki Takes Place In MCU Timeline
text:
Loki will pick up with the God of Mischief both before and after his death in Avengers: Endgame, and here's how it fits into the MCU timeline.
Here's where Loki fits into the Marvel Cinematic Universe timeline. First released as the third of Marvel's Disney+ shows, Loki brings back Tom Hiddleston as the titular God of Mischief, following on from his disappearance with the Space Stone in Avengers: Endgame. That movie fully introduced time travel to the MCU (after it was first explored in Doctor Strange), and Loki takes things further, revealing the Time Variance Authority (TVA), which keeps watch over the timeline and multiverse, with the Loki season 1 ending carrying some major implications for both.
All of that means the MCU timeline (or timelines) is central to Loki, which feels particularly necessary after Avengers: Endgame. That movie created several branches, and while most were closed by the time the end credits rolled, there were some discrepancies and disagreements over exactly how it all worked. That's something Loki puts right, but just where - or rather, when - exactly do its own events take place, and how does it fit into the MCU overall?
Related: Everything We Know About Loki Season 3
The answer to where Loki fits in the MCU timeline is a slightly convoluted one. Because he teleported away with the Tesseract, creating a new branched timeline, Loki takes place after The Avengers in 2012, with the God of Mischief still a villain and several years away from redemption. However, the show is also releasing after Endgame, and it's clear the film's events have also taken place, because the time heist had to have happened in order for Loki to have teleported away (something the series shows and addresses). That puts it in a strange position of existing in several places of the timeline, or perhaps none at all would be more accurate, but it does make sense given the involvement of the TVA.
The TVA operates outside of time and space, meaning it doesn't have to adhere to the same rules of the MCU timeline. While Loki teleports away into another timeline during Endgame, he is found by the TVA and taken to their headquarters, meaning that he too now exists outside of the timeline itself. That puts the character in a fascinating position, allowing for several different possibilities for where he might go next. Loki itself features different time periods - especially given Loki season 2's time-slipping - and so the character can be shown all across the MCU's timeline, rather than in one fixed point, even though his journey is more linearly picking up from that point in 2012.
Related: Loki’s Complete MCU Timeline Explained
Marvel Phase 4 is utilizing several different timeline tricks. Black Widow is a prequel set between Captain America: Civil War and Avengers: Infinity War; WandaVision took place just after Avengers: Endgame, but mimicked multiple decades; Eternals spans thousands of years. It's an approach that helps massively expand the scope of the MCU and naturally fits as it looks to open up the multiverse too. Loki works well for both of those because of its ability to explore different timelines, including the many branches created in Endgame, while also creating a new character arc following on from The Avengers.

title: Quantum Leap Season 2 Will Feature More Flashbacks To Ben's Past, Teases Producer
text:
Quantum Leap season 2 will incorporate various flashbacks to Ben’s past, as teased in new comments from directing producer Chris Grismer.
Warning: Spoilers for Quantum Leap season 2
Quantum Leap season 2 will include more flashbacks to Ben's past, according to producer Chris Grismer. It was a rocky return for Ben Song (Raymond Lee), as the reboot's main character had to complete an exceptionally dangerous leap without the help of his team. Although he's ultimately successful, Ben later learns that he's actually been missing and presumed dead for three years. But before he can even begin to process the news, it's off to the next leap.
In an interview with TV Insider, Grismer shares that Quantum Leap season 2 will include more flashbacks to Ben's past. Grismer, who is also a directing producer on the series, mentions that the flashbacks will appear "as they're needed" which is something that's established in the premiere episode. Read Grismer's quote below:
“There are various flashbacks throughout the season, for sure. They appear when they’re needed.”
In the debut episode of season 2, titled "This Took Too Long," Ben has a moment where he flashes back to Addison (Caitlin Bassett). Toward the end of the installment, Ben thinks back to a conversation he had with Addison where he expresses fear of losing her because of their work on grand projects like Quantum Leap. She responds calmly, and with a gradually beaming smile, and says: "Then you'll come find me." The conversation is clearly significant, given the news that Ben will receive moments later.
After successfully completing the objective behind his leap, Ian (Mason Alexander Park) finds Ben. It's a heavy moment, but the emotion of their reunion doesn't land, With obvious reluctance, Ian tells Ben about how he's been missing and presumed dead. It sets up the rest of Quantum Leap season 2, but it also fulfills the flashback. Ben has lost Addison, he's lost time with her, and he has to find her again.
Related: Quantum Leap 2022 Cast & Character Guide
It's an early example of how the reboot, which airs Wednesdays on NBC and streams on Peacock, will weave in flashbacks. It's an important way of fleshing out the main character, which in itself is a key goal if the new Quantum Leap hopes to eventually have a chance of matching the original's popularity and largely enduring cultural relevance.
Source: TV Insider

title: How To Get The Agaou Throwing Axe In Cyberpunk 2077: Phantom Liberty
text:
The Phantom Liberty DLC for Cyberpunk 2077 added the Agaou Throwing Axe, one of the most broken weapons in the game. Here’s how to get it.
Unlocking the Agaou Throwing Axe in Cyberpunk 2077’s Phantom Liberty DLC is a great idea, as the new weapon added can do some impressive damage to opponents. The throwable machete is part of Phantom Liberty, a paid expansion for CD Projekt Red’s popular RPG. The Agaou is considered an iconic piece of gear and one of the coolest new weapons in Cyberpunk 2077. What makes it so special is that it can be thrown at enemies for massive damage but, in addition to that, it also discharges an AoE shock effect onto them.
This additional electric damage not only eats away at their life bar but also has a considerable explosion radius that affects nearby characters. What makes the Agaou Throwing Axe a special weapon is that it has a perk that grants a 125% headshot damage multiplier. With a throwing weapon build, the potential of the Agaou can be enhanced significantly, especially if you are using a Sandevistan that allows you to slow time and throw the axe with critical precision. This is easily one of the strongest melee weapons in the Phantom Liberty DLC and one that should immediately be sought out if you are looking to improve your damage output.
More Cyberpunk: 10 Most Powerful New Weapons (Phantom Liberty DLC)
Unlocking the Agaou Throwing Axe in Cyberpunk 2077: Phantom Liberty is fairly simple, especially when considering how powerful the weapon actually is. To get it, you will need to head to the southeastern portion of Dogtown, a new area added with the DLC. There, you will find a location with increased criminal activity, which will be the base where you can get the Agaou.
To reach the destination, you can fast-travel to the Luxor Wellness Spa waypoint and start heading south until you see the icon with the three skulls. This is where your enemies will be, and where you will finally obtain the Agaou in Cyberpunk 2077: Phantom Liberty. The next step is cleaning the house, so you can eliminate all the criminals in the area and make your way through the building. The strategy you employ here is irrelevant, so you can either go in guns blazing or try a stealthier approach.
The important thing is that you eliminate the big boss at the end, named Ayo Zarin. They fight primarily with melee weapons and have a large chunk of health, so adapt your combat strategy accordingly. Upon defeating them, you will be able to loot the Agaou Throwing Axe off Ayo Zarin’s body, along with several other items. These include a cache access card, which grants you access to a nearby loot room in Cyberpunk 2077: Phantom Liberty.

title: Assassin's Creed Mirage: How To Find & Use Mysterious Shards (Nehal's Calling Quest)
text:
The Mysterious Shards are key to unlocking high-level gear and discovering what mystery Nehal is attempting to uncover in Assassin’s Creed: Mirage.
Mysterious Shards are a bonus item throughout Assassin’s Creed: Mirage that can be used to unlock extra bonus items. Players will encounter a Shard early in the game at the end of the tutorial, but it will not be until the end of the first main investigation in Baghdad that players will be able to encounter them again. This will happen when Roshan tells Basim to reconnect with Nehal after he admits that he is troubled by how they parted.
Mysterious Shards are one way to find premium Gear, although they will only unlock one full set of Gear in total. Players can find more Gear by opening chests, but Mysterious Shards are also the only way to finish Neha's Calling Investigation. This will lead players to search for Mysterious Shards and find a hidden chamber.
Related: "A Triumphant Homage" - Assassin's Creed Mirage Review
When Basim finds Nehal, one of the recurring secondary characters in Assassin’s Creed: Mirage, again she will ask him to investigate the Mysterious Shards to help her out. This will start Nehal’s Calling Quest on the Investigation menu, and Basim will have to track down a mysterious area in the desert. She will give him a couple of clues as to where to find this area, and Basim will agree to try to help her with her obsession.
This is also the time when Basim can start finding Mysterious Shards, as before that while they are listed as a collectible in each region on the map of Baghdad, it will not be possible to find them. Like with Dervis’ Artifacts, players will have to find them by wandering around various parts of the map. They will spawn randomly, and when players approach they will learn that Order members are transporting them around Baghdad.
Once Basim has found an Order member with a Mysterious Shard, they can follow them throughout the streets of historical Baghdad to find a good place to ambush them. Players have to assassinate the Order member to get the Shard, but this might be dangerous as most of them also travel with guards. Look for hiding places along the road to lure guards away and whittle down their numbers. Once the Order member is alone, do the same thing to take them down and get their Shard piece.
The best way is typically to find a haystack, as Basim will not likely be noticed, and it will count as a stealth kill even if civilians and guards are nearby. Hide in a haystack and pull the Order member in to assassinate them.
Basim can find the place by searching for the right area, as the clues suggest that it is near an oasis north of the ‘Aqarquf Dunes. There is a Synchronization Point right next to an oasis drawing on the Northeast corner of the map, and that is where Basim should head. Dive into the water and into a cave and follow it through until the end to find the chamber with pillars inside.
Each pillar will require a different number of Mysterious Shards, and once Basim has enough to fill one he can put his Shards in that pillar and exchange them for a piece of Gear. The first one available is the Samsaama, a special dagger that can steal health every fifth hit, and the gear found in the chamber is already fully upgraded. Find all the Mysterious Shards to fully unlock the chamber, the gear hidden within, and complete Nehal’s Calling Quest in Assassin’s Creed: Mirage.

title: Assassin’s Creed Mirage’s Best Armor Is A Huge Disappointment
text:
One of the most elusive quest rewards in Assassin’s Creed Mirage is fittingly effective, but it doesn’t really fit into the game satisfyingly.
Assassin's Creed Mirage doesn't quite employ the extensive gear systems of its RPG predecessors, but there is still a decent number of options when it comes to what outfit to wear. The wardrobe Basim can collect throughout the game is largely comprised of robes resembling those traditionally worn by the Hidden Ones – often primarily white or off-white and hooded – but some, and particularly some costumes, have a bit more variety, including a few that are definitely more armored than Basim's default attire. The most exclusive outfit in the game, however, is disappointing compared to the verisimilitude offered by most others.
[Warning: The following article contains minor spoilers for Assassin's Creed Mirage.]
Taking players to 9th century Baghdad, AC Mirage is a refreshing return to the series' central, long-running conflict between the Hidden Ones and the Order of the Ancients – two shadowy organizations that would manifest the Assassin Brotherhood and Templar Order respectively in later centuries. Mirage's gameplay reflects this return to the series' earlier era as well, in part including a number of outfits which don't have defensive stats, but do provide unique perks. There is also a certain set of collectibles, which offers a mysterious set of armor as its ultimate reward, a quest line which has seen multiple variations in the series since Assassin's Creed 2.
Related: "A Triumphant Homage" - Assassin's Creed Mirage Review
Fairly early in Assassin's Creed Mirage, Nehal tells Basim of a supposed treasure hidden somewhere near an oasis in the desert north of Baghdad, beginning a quest called "The Ancient Place." The aptly named Northern Oasis is indeed holding such a treasure – three, in fact, locked behind mysterious mechanisms in a cave only accessible by diving to the bottom of the oasis' water. The mechanisms are unlocked by inserting a certain number of Mysterious Shards, found on the person of and taken from (either through pickpocketing or killing and looting) people connected to the Order throughout Baghdad.
Five Shards will unlock the most coveted prize: Milad's Outfit. The trait unique to Milad's Outfit, Forgotten Terror, makes it so a bright flash of lightning disorients nearby enemies whenever a successful air assassination is performed (i.e. jumping on an enemy from above to assassinate them). Especially in the later sections of the game, when Milad's Outfit is likely to be acquired and a breadth of other tools in Basim's possession make Mirage's dangerous combat less so, this flash of lightning can help tremendously. Not only does it give the player an immediate advantage over surrounding enemies in a fight, it also makes it so performing an assassination and fleeing the scene is much easier.
Related: "What [Players] Loved First" - Simon Arseneault On Assassin's Creed Mirage
While helpful in a variety of gameplay situations, Milad's Outfit looks a bit ridiculous, like an over-designed suit from a Marvel movie, and feels entirely disconnected from the rest of the game. AC Mirage – despite featuring Basim as its protagonist – actually has very little to do with the Isu. Simply collecting these Mysterious Shards and slotting them into an ancient mechanism is far less interesting than a reward that has a meaningful connection to the story. For instance, the Armor of Altaïr, which can be acquired by Ezio in Assassin's Creed 2, deepens the connection between the two master assassins, fits into the story of Ezio recovering Altaïr's codex, and is in sync with the general aesthetic of the Assassin Brotherhood.
Milad's Outfit's only connection to Mirage's story is that Order members are seeking it, and apparently covet the Mysterious Shards. Milad is never mentioned in any other capacity, and the outfit is woefully anachronistic. It even goes so far as to alter Basim's voice, making it deeper and slightly digitized – an understandable feat for a bit of Isu technology, but it feels shoe-horned into Mirage like something of an obligation. Having powerful and unique rewards for potentially lengthy side adventures is always welcome, but the reward for collecting the Mysterious Shards in Assassin's Creed Mirage, Milad's Outfit, is quite a letdown. Luckily, its powerful perk can still be utilized with its appearance changed by equipping a Costume.

title: Assassin's Creed Mirage: How to Find (& Open) Gear Chests
text:
If Basim wants to upgrade his weapons and outfits or find new ones, he will have to find as many Gear Chests as possible in Assassin’s Creed: Mirage.
Gear Chests can be found throughout the city of Baghdad in Assassin’s Creed: Mirage and Basim will want to find and open them as soon as possible to receive the best gear in the game. Gear Chests are located in each region, but they are not automatically marked on the map until Basim spots them. Therefore, learning how to spot and mark them early will be essential.
Gear Chests are the best way to find good armor and weapons within the gameplay of Assassin’s Creed: Mirage. Basim must find these chests in order to get upgrade sheets for the gear he already has for the Blacksmith to make improvements as well. Some of these chests can be opened when Basim finds them, others need a special item to unlock them.
Related: "A Triumphant Homage" - Assassin's Creed Mirage Review
Each region of the map will list the number of Gear Chests in that region. That lets Basim know how many to look for, but it does not automatically mark where they are even after activating a Synchronization Point. To mark them on the map, Basim must spot them with either Enkidu or his own Eagle Vision.
Enkidu can be scared away if you use him too close to a Restricted Area with a lot of guards, or near where there are archers on the rooftops.
To use Enkidu’s Eye, activate him and look for gold lines on the skyline. Focus on them and fly closer if necessary and Enkidu will mark it for you. This could also reveal other valuable items not automatically marked, such as Mysterious Shards, but look out for other gold lines as well. Basim can do the same thing using his Eagle Vision, but he will have to get much closer physically to do so.
Once the Gear Chest is marked, Basim will have to navigate to them, and these chests are almost always in Restricted Areas and behind locked or barred doors. This means Basim will have to take down a guard with a key or knock the bar off the door from a window to enter the room with the chest, as is the case in the Metal Factory. Try to employ stealth gameplay mechanics to do so, as being seen will cause Basim's Notoriety to increase.
Once you reach a Gear Chest, opening it might present another challenge to Basim. Some Gear Chests can be opened automatically, but others will require a Merchant Token, which is one of three types of Khidmah Tokens in the game. These Merchant Tokens can be found by completing Contracts, and some Gear Chests will require them to be opened. If Basim does not have any Merchant Tokens, he will have to return later to open the Gear Chest. Once he collects the Gear, Basim will be able to continue his journey through Baghdad in Assassin’s Creed: Mirage.

title: Assassin's Creed Mirage: How To Infiltrate the Damascus Gate Prison
text:
One of your missions in Assassin's Creed Mirage involves infiltrating the heavily guarded Damascus Gate Prison to save an important rebel leader.
The Damascus Gate Prison is one of the first fortresses you'll have to infiltrate in Assassin's Creed Mirage as part of the first act of the game's story. Your mission here is to rescue the rebel leader Ali ibn Muhammad, preferably without getting caught by the many guards who swarm this large outpost. There are many ways to break into the Prison, from fighting your way inside to adopting a clever disguise.
The Gate Prison can be found by checking the World map and looking southwest from the Metal Factory, close to the Iron Gate that leads outside the main city. Depending on your notoriety level in Assassin's Creed Mirage, approaching this area could be fairly easy or incredibly hard to even show your face. Feel free to scout the location beforehand to know where guards patrol and how many are within the jail.
Related: "A Triumphant Homage" - Assassin's Creed Mirage Review
While you could get into the Damascus Gate Prison by fighting your way inside, you can also ask for help from the Merchant or Rebel groups found nearby. Those who have no patience for a stealthy approach could take out guards in battle as they fight waves of enemies to reach Ali. However, this approach is obviously pretty dangerous in Assassin's Creed Mirage and would require you to have many healing items to recover from injuries.
The main character, Basim, can heal using Elixirs that restore your health to its maximum capacity, but you may only hold up to two at a time by this point in the game's story.
Close to the Iron Gate by the jail, you can meet with a merchant who can help you sneak into the Prison by disguising you as their assistant. This favor isn't free, though, as you will have to pay the merchant one Merchant's Favor Token. This unique currency ordinarily gets you discounts with vendors across the city and is gained by either pickpocketing people on the streets or completing different Contracts in Assassin's Creed Mirage.
Related: Assassin's Creed Mirage: How to Find (& Complete) Contracts
Another way to get into the Prison is through the rebel you can talk to located to the east of the jail, who can rally a group of warriors to mount an assault against the Prison while you sneak in. This distraction may help more than the merchant since it takes out more than a few guards who could have exposed you inside the fortress. A Power Token that normally resets your notoriety will be needed to grant this favor from the rebel group.
No matter how you decide to infiltrate the Damascus Gate Prison in Assassin's Creed Mirage, you will still have to sneak past or eliminate several guards to find and rescue Ali ibn Muhammad.

title: Starfield: The Best Physical Skill Builds
text:
While Combat skills seem to be the most appealing ones, you can excel in Starfield with a well-rounded Physical build. Here are some of the best.
Using Starfield’s best Physical skill builds can be an easy way of powering through opponents and getting through the game without major inconveniences – all while not excluding the challenge factor that outer space involves. Such builds are centered on grounded exploration and combat rather than using your spaceship and usually focus on survivability, combat power, and even stealth prowess. As Starfield is quite an open-ended RPG when it comes to skill trees, you can mix and match abilities to round out the perfect build. In fact, you are incentivized to do so, as most of the best Physical builds in the game stem from such combinations.
Physical skill builds do not necessarily mean that you will only invest in abilities from that tree, but that will be the main focus when building your character. You will likely be using many Combat skills in Starfield to perfect your Physical build, as combat abilities allow you to exterminate opponents while surviving hard battles. There are endless possibilities on how to build your character, especially because Starfield’s lack of a level cap essentially allows you to max out all of your skills, but focusing on specific builds while progressing through the game’s many stories can be a great way of making your experience more pleasant.
Related: 10 Starfield Quests You Definitely Want To Avoid
A very fun Physical build to play around with is what you can call a space samurai build. Its focus is high survivability rates mixed with close and personal face-to-face combat with melee weapons – preferably a sword, which can make the build live up to its name. Mixed up with Ronin, one of the easiest Starfield character backgrounds to start off with, players can initiate their progress on the build from the get-go. While the damage output will largely stem from the Dueling skill on the Combat tree, you will want to invest most of your points on the skills from the Physical tree.
The Space Samurai Build in Starfield
Physical Skills
 
Other Skills
 
For starters, your first priority should be the Wellness stat. Though there are objectives to unlock each level of the skill, you should try to max out all four levels as quickly as possible. This will boost your total HP by 40% and allow you to get in your enemies’ faces with an improved safety measure.
The second priority should be Pain Tolerance in the second row. You can either take it to level 3, which will reduce the physical damage you take by 15%, or max it out to get a 5% chance to completely ignore physical damage when your health is low.
The next obvious step is to maximize Martial Arts in the Physical tree as much as possible. This ability will increase your chances of landing a critical hit with a melee weapon by 15%, get a 15% boost to the chance of disarming your opponent, take 10% less damage, and reflect 50% back when blocking. This, of course, requires you to use some of Starfield’s best melee weapons, such as the Wakizashi. The last necessary skill is called Rejuvenation, and it will allow you to restore HP in and outside of battle if fully maxed out.
If you want, you can throw in a few extra skills to allow you to have different approaches to combat. Using Stealth and Concealment, both on the Physical tree, will give you the opportunity to walk around unnoticed, get close to opponents, and strike them down for 10x the regular damage you would normally do. This goes against the traditional samurai code and leans more into something of a shinobi, but everything is allowed in space. This is a fantastic complement to the build, leaving open combat as a second option to your stealthy slaughter.
Another similar build that focuses on melee damage is the boxer. Unlike the samurai, however, you will not be using melee weapons, but instead your bare hands. This build uses most of the high survivability skills offered from the previous skills, but takes advantage of the abilities that allow you to fight with your fists.
There is a decent amount of skills in Starfield that give you bonuses for not using weapons, so this is what the build is centered around.
The Boxer Build in Starfield
Physical Skills
 
Other Skills
 
One of the main differences is that the Boxing skill from the Physical tree will be featured front and center with this build. The ability, when leveled up to 4, will allow you to do 100% more damage with unarmed attacks and give you a chance to knock down opponents. You will also consume less O2 when running in combat and using powered attacks. Another important skill in Starfield for the boxer build is Neurostrikes. At level 4, you will have a 20% chance of stunning an NPC with an unarmed attack, dealing additional EM damage, and knocking down nearby opponents when you stun an enemy.
A skill that goes well with the samurai build but is essential for the boxer build is Gymnastics. This will allow you to use the combat slide and take less fall damage, while also increasing your jump height and overall running speed after using the combat slide or mantling.
The boxer build benefits from speed to get close to opponents and fight against them, so having this Physical skill unlocked can improve that strategy. The boxer in Starfield is equivalent to an overpowered monk in any fantasy RPG.
Survivability is key with the boxer build as well, so Wellness, Pain Tolerance, and Rejuvenation are also essential.
The last Physical build to use in Starfield is different from the two previous ones, which were focused on melee damage. The unstoppable tank build will also have a lot of survivability involved, but the focus here will be using powerful weapons to melt through opponents without ever having to stop or fear enemy encounters.
The idea is to be a complete juggernaut. Aside from Wellness, Pain Tolerance, and Rejuvenation, you will want to invest in all 4 levels of Weight Lifting. This Physical skill allows you to carry more weight and, thus, comfortably carry several heavy weapons and shotguns – you also get a 50% resistance boost to stagger.
The Unstoppable Tank Build in Starfield
Physical Skills
 
Other Skills
 
Another Physical skill to use with this tank build is Energy Weapon Dissipation. This will reduce the energy damage you take and give you a chance to reflect it back to the opponent when your health is lower than 50% in Starfield. Because you are expected to take damage and, possibly be injured, Cellular Regeneration can also be a helpful Physical skill to invest in.
Aside from the Physical tree, there will also be important modifications to the skills from the Combat tree to make this Physical build work. Instead of Dueling, you will want to use Ballistics, Shotgun Certification, Demolitions, Heavy Certification, Rapid Reloading, and Targeting.
This will allow you to make the most out of shotguns and heavy weapons, as well as deal more damage when firing without aiming down your sights. With this, you become a walking grenadier and arsenal that can get close to opponents without fear of dying, exterminate them, and proceed to the next one.
There are several different Physical builds to use in Starfield, and these are some of the best and most varied ones to use so far.

title: Starfield: How To Make Your Character As OP As Possible
text:
Explore planets, battle monsters, fight pirates, and travel through space with a chip on your shoulder thanks to this Starfield OP Character guide.
Because there is no level cap in Starfield, making your character as OP as possible is merely a matter of maxing out all 82 skills. That being said, it will be long before you can reach that stature. Furthermore, there is an argument to be made about your background, traits, weapons, and armor, all of which play a role in making your character as OP as possible.
Nonetheless, you can do so if you want to be the most powerful spacer across Starfields 120 Star Systems. That being said, you will have to commit to a lengthy and scripted playthrough to make it happen. Because making your character the most powerful in Starfield requires more than selecting the most powerful perks and weapons.
Related: How To Build The Most Ridiculously OP Ship In Starfield
When it comes to making your character as OP as possible in Starfield, it largely depends on the starting background, traits, and skills you choose, with the latter being the most crucial. This is because they essentially outline your character's playstyle and, thus, how effective they are in combat and conversation.
Players looking to make their character as OP as possible should also consider getting the best Starfield Starborn Powers.
Your character's Background and Traits don't make or break how OP they are. However, they do significantly speed up the process at the start of the game. As a result, it's best to start on a fresh playthrough to follow to create an OP character.
The background you choose in Starfield is significant because it grants you three starting skills. While there are several best backgrounds in Starfield to choose from, you will want to go with the Soldier background to make your character as OP as possible. This is because, with Soldier, you get starting skills in Ballistics, Boost Pack Training, and Fitness. These are all skills you will push to get early on, so you could save those skill points and grab them now with the Soldier background.
Traits are optional in Starfield, and you can select up to three. The kicker is that while you can lose traits in Starfield, you can't add them later on - another reason why starting on a fresh playthrough is best. The best traits to pick in Starfield to make your character as OP as possible are Alien DNA, Wanted, and Introvert.
Alien DNA is arguably the most important because it provides more health and oxygen. While healing and food items are less effective with this trait, you will level up your character's Wellness skill, eventually rendering these effects obsolete in your game. You will also want to grab the Wanted trait. You will gain extra XP from bounties, and this trait will make your character OP by allowing you to deal extra damage when your health is low.
The final trait to acquire is Introvert. All it does is reduce your oxygen consumption when traveling alone. However, it's the perfect trait to combine with the Isolation skill, which is one of the skills you will be looking to max out.
The path to making your character as OP as possible in Starfield mainly depends on your chosen skills. Of course, the end goal of making your character as OP as possible should be to max out every skill in every skill tree in Starfield. That being said, some skills are more important to focus on than others. According to Khraze Gaming on YouTube, to make your character as OP as possible, you will want to focus on fully maxing out every one of these skills first.

By maxing out these skills, you will have the most OP character in Starfield. That being said, it will take a while to max out all the skills listed; that's why you will want to use this trick to level up fast in Starfield. The more XP you farm, the more skills you can buy; thus, the faster and more OP your character will become.
An Outpost XP Farm early on is also another great way to grind XP and Credits that will contribute to making an OP character.
Because you're focusing on leveling many skills in your Combat skill tree, any gun you use will automatically rip enemies to shreds. That being said, it's still worth looking at the most powerful weapons in Starfield. Though these weapons are already good, they will be even more powerful in your hands. What's more, because you're focusing on maxing out the "Weapon Engineering" skill in your Science skill tree, you can add mods to these weapons to make them even as OP as possible.
Your armor is the finishing touch to take your OP character to the next level. While the Starborn Suit is the best armor in the game, you will have to wait a long time to get your hands on it. As a result, it is recommended to get the Mark 1 Spacesuit early in Starfield or the Mantis ship, suit, and backpack. title: Assassin’s Creed Mirage: How To Assassinate Fazil The Great Scholar (Without Getting Caught)
text:
An important target to assassinate in Assassin's Creed Mirage is Fazil the Great Scholar, an evil man who is hard to take down without getting caught.
Fazil the Great Scholar is one of your targets to assassinate in Assassin's Creed Mirage, found in a large Symposium that can be difficult to infiltrate without getting caught. This leader of the Order of Abbasiyah has been conducting human experiments to try and control dark magics. The perverted knowledge wielded by Fazil must be stopped, but his actions' insidious and hidden nature makes him hard to find.
The mission to eliminate Fazil begins in The Great Symposium, a massive academic building with twisting turns and multiple floors. Before you even start, use Eagle Sight to look for places that might hold potential clues regarding the Great Scholar's location. The restricted area here is smaller than Assassin's Creed Mirage's large map size, letting you focus on specific points of interest to investigate.
Related: "A Triumphant Homage" - Assassin's Creed Mirage Review
Basim can blend into the background of spots throughout the Symposium in Assassin's Creed Mirage and eavesdrop on different people to learn more about Fazil's whereabouts. From the room where you start in the area, head right and turn left before reaching a set of stairs leading to the upper levels. Find a distraught librarian here talking to someone about how they lost an important book of Fazil's.
Head outside to find two speakers near a bench talking about rumors of underground passageways below the House of Wisdom. An individual named Kahraman can be spoken to about these tunnels, but they will deny any possibility of secret routes unless you have proper payment. You will need to give them a Scholar Khidmah Token in Assassin's Creed Mirage to bribe Kahraman into telling you more.
Khidmah Tokens can be earned by pickpocketing people along the city streets or by completing various Contracts. Each has a different effect and can be used to purchase favors from different characters you meet.
The two speakers may also mention that a gardener might have a key that unlocks the path into the underground area. You should be able to find this gardener close to the roof on one of the highest floors you can climb up to. Activate your Eagle Sight to pinpoint the worker's location ahead of time, and be careful not to get spotted as you try to keep your notoriety low in Assassin's Creed Mirage.
You can find the path leading to the underground passages next to a Gatekeeper, who guards an ornate blue door in the same place next to the stairs leading to the librarian. When you talk to this NPC, they will ask Basim, "Those Who Came Before are...?" This is clearly some code demanding a specific response in Assassin's Creed Mirage that you might be able to learn by exploring the House of Wisdom.
Now, the door behind the Gatekeeper can also be opened by the key you get from the gardener, so there are multiple options. However, if you want to avoid sneaking past the Gatekeeper to use the key, you will find the passcode inside the book the librarian lost. If you follow the librarian from where you eavesdropped on them, you can use Eagle Sight to spot the book in Assassin's Creed Mirage on a balcony to the northwest of the Symposium.
You must avoid some guards to reach Fazil's book in a restricted section of the Symposium past the librarian, which you can see is glowing orange when you use Eagle Sight.
The rest of the passcode revealed in the book is "Those Who Shall Return," a phrase that will convince the Gatekeeper in Assassin's Creed Mirage to open the door. The room you enter is scattered with different scrolls documenting Fazil's recent works, including a Great Work in the basement. Go ahead and move a bookshelf in this space to reveal a set of stairs going down into a Restricted Area within a series of tunnels.
This section of the assassination may be the trickiest to complete without getting into a fight due to the many guards who patrol the passages underneath the House of Wisdom. Mark enemies with Eagle Sight to ensure you don't get surprised as you explore this labyrinth in Assassin's Creed Mirage. Use your Whistle ability to lure guards into corners for quick and silent kills that fail to alert anyone lurking around this area.
Eventually, you will find a room with three guards commenting on how they plan to use "volunteers" for the Great Scholar's experiments near some iron cages and shackles. Wait until one of them leaves before using throwing knives to make the red pots in the room explode, which will either kill them or cause a distraction for easy assassinations. Travel a bit further to the left of the room to a larger prison space in Assassin's Creed Mirage.
Near the holding cells, here is a note from Fazil saying that all those he conducts his ritual on must be wearing the right clothing before being brought to him. Go through the first cell door you see and travel under a break in the right wall to discover one of the Great Scholar's previous victims in Assassin's Creed Mirage. Disguise yourself with the clothes from the corpse to act as the next willing participant in Fazil's demented studies.​​​​​​​
The WhitePatient's Robe you put on lets you blend in perfectly, getting a free escort from one of Fazil's soldiers when you go past the prison door. Descending another staircase places you in a terrifying ritual chamber, Fazil's library of taboo knowledge and dark practices in Assassin's Creed Mirage. In the center is a mechanism that resembles a flower where Fazil is arguing with others about interruptions to his "Great Work."
Simply press the Blend In option at the center of the machine to start a cutscene that lets you assassinate Fazil the Great Scholar without getting caught in Assassin's Creed Mirage.

title: How To Remove Tharchiate Withering (& Other Curses) In Baldur’s Gate 3
text:
Curses like Tharchiate Withering can be a pain to deal with in Baldur's Gate 3. Luckily, there is an easy way to cure yourself of these afflictions.
Curses are not very common in Baldur's Gate 3, but if you are unfortunate enough to come across one, you will need a way to remove it. The Level 3 Spell Bestow Curse can inflict multiple curses, affecting checks, saving throws, health, and/or attacks. Cursed items can provide useful bonuses at terrible cost. You may even get a particularly nasty curse called Tharchiate Withering.
Tharchiate Withering comes from the Tharchiate Codex, a cursed book on necromancy found in the Elminster Vault. Tharchiate Withering decreases your Constitution by five points. This can dangerously limit your health. Luckily, there's a simple move most players have easy access to, whether personally or through a companion. Even if, somehow, you lack the resources to cure your curse, you can find them.
Related: Should You Equip Cursed Items In Baldur's Gate 3?
 In order to get rid of curses like Tharchiate Withering in Baldur's Gate 3, you will need to know a spell called Remove Curse. Remove Curse is a Level 3 Abjuration Spell that removes curses of all types, from enemy spells to cursed items. This spell is available to Clerics, Warlocks, Wizards, and Paladins of the Oath of Devotion. It's an Action Spell, so you can quickly recover from any curse that may afflict you. You will need to be at Level 5 or higher to cast the spell yourself.
If you open the Tharchiate Withering but find yourself without the classes possessing the needed spell, don't worry. Since Shadowheart is a useful High Cleric, she knows Remove Curse. Simply direct her to use the spell, and the Curse will disappear. You could teach the spell to Gale or Wyll since they also have the needed classes to learn Remove Curse, but it is easier to bring Shadowheart along.
If you still lack a companion or class to cast Remove Curse, you will need to find a Scroll of Remove Curse. This is a rare scroll worth 100 gold pieces. You can purchase the scroll from merchants or stumble upon it while collecting loot. There is no definite area where all players can find a Scroll of Remove Curse. If you can only remove a curse by hoping you find a specific scroll somewhere in Baldur's Gate 3, you are better off avoiding the Tharchiate Codex or any items that bestow curses.

title: Every Wordle Answer: All Words Used So Far (Updated Daily)
text:
Wordle is a simple daily word game that has taken the internet by storm. With only 6 chances to get the right answer, players may need a little help.
Wordle is a simple word-guessing game that tasks players with solving a five-word puzzle using letter position clues. Wordle presents the player with six rows of five empty boxes. Simply enter a random five-letter word and the website highlights certain letters in green if they are correct, yellow if they are correct but in the wrong spot, or grey if they are not in the word at all. With this information, players need to try to figure out the word within the six guesses to be successful.
These types of guessing games have been around for a long time. One of the originals was called Mastermind, where players are tasked with guessing a row of colored pegs that utilizes the same hint systems found in Wordle. If players would like to try the game for themselves, it can be found on the Wordle website, which creates a new puzzle every day, keeps track of players' win streaks and guess distribution, and has a popular sharing ability.
Comedian Patton Oswalt scored a Wordle win-in-two, even though he only got a single misplaced letter from his starting word. He shared his win from July 15th on Twitter and called it "Lucky!"
With a new Wordle added every day, players may need a little help with the more difficult words, and having a strong starting word is important. Players may not have time to work out the puzzle solution every day, or perhaps they just want to keep their streak going but are having too much difficulty with the daily word. Whatever the reason, players can find every daily Wordle answer used so far in 2023 below.
Looking for last year's answers? They're all here below for archiving needs.
Simple games, like Wordle, are the perfect small distraction for the day. The game itself doesn't take up too much time and is a nice break during the standard morning routine. Being able to compare with friends on social media sites makes Wordle even more addicting by adding the element of competition. With the win streak tracking feature and social media sharing button, Wordle is the perfect little puzzle to spend 3-5 minutes on during a workday.

title: Loki Season 2: Why Wasn't OB's Memory Wiped By He Who Remains?
text:
Loki season 2 has confirmed that Agents of the Time Variance Authority got their memories wiped by He Who Remains, so what's going on with Ouroboros?
Warning! This post contains SPOILERS for Loki season 2, episode 1
Loki season 2's premiere features an exciting mystery surrounding its newest character and instant MCU breakout Ouroborus (Ke Huy Quan). Also known as O.B., it appears as though the head of the Repairs and Advancement department has a fully intact memory unlike his fellow agents working at the Time Variance Authority. This begs the question as to why He Who Remains allowed Ouroboros to keep said memory.
In Loki season 1's ending, He Who Remains (Jonathan Majors) was revealed as the true founder of the TVA, having created the organization to help maintain the Sacred Timeline where his variants (like Kang) would never exist. To that end, several fictions were put in place to keep the agents of the TVA complacent such as the Time-Keepers. Likewise, it's been revealed that agents like Mobius (Owen Wilson) and many others continually had their minds wiped, preventing them from remembering their past lives as variants while also ensuring they wouldn't question the TVA's true purpose. However, Loki season 2's premiere implies O.B. never had his mind wiped.
Related: Loki Season 2 Cast Guide: Every New & Returning Marvel Character
As the chief (and only) engineer at the TVA's Repairs and Advancement department, Ouroboros is a key part of the Time Variance Authority. As such, Loki season 2's premiere confirms he's in charge of all the technology and inner workings of the TVA. He even wrote the entire TVA guidebook. However, Agent Mobius struggles to remember their history and even O.B.'s name due to the mind wiping by He Who Remains. Conversely, Ouroboros is able to recall their history with no issue, including his conversations with Loki after the God of Mischief time-slipped back into the distant past of the TVA. This establishes that O.B. possibly never had his mind wiped by He Who Remains.
It stands to reason that Ouroboros has always been far too integral to the TVA's operations to be mind-wiped. After all, it certainly seems as though the entire organization would fall apart without him. While the full extent of his knowledge remains to be seen, it's possible that O.B. may have been aware of He Who Remains' role in founding the TVA. Although he seems innocent enough, it's quite possible that O.B. knew the truth about the Time Variance Authority's true purpose and the truth about his fellow agents all along. There's also the possibility that Ouroboros was so isolated by his work that he wasn't deemed a threat the same way the other agents would have been.
Related: Every Loki Season 2 Episode 1 MCU Easter Egg & Reference
The TVA looks to be at risk of being destroyed thanks to the newly expanding multiverse. Needing to retrofit the TVA's Time Loom so it doesn't overload from the massive influx of raw temporal energy, perhaps O.B. will point Loki and Mobius in the direction of Victor Timely, the confirmed Kang variant who's set to appear. Existing as an inventor of time travel giving lectures in 1901, perhaps Timely can help O.B. stabilize the Time Loom as a replacement for He Who Remains (who remains no more). At any rate, O.B.'s intact memory will likely play a big factor going forward in Loki season 2.
